thread.title: Fossil teeth show earliest sign of people in southern Asia
thread.title_full: Fossil teeth show earliest sign of people in southern Asia - US News

author: USNews
title: Fossil teeth show earliest sign of people in southern Asia
text:
Dozens of fossil teeth from Chinese cave show earliest sign of our species in southern Asia This photo provided by the journal Nature shows human upper teeth found in the Fuyan Cave of Hunan province in southern China. They are among dozens of fossil human teeth more than 80,000 years old that were recovered from the cave, providing the oldest clear indication by far that people lived in southern Asia that long ago. Maria Martinon-Torres, of University College London in England, and colleagues report the discovery in a paper released by the journal Nature on Wednesday, Oct. 14, 2015. (S. Xing/Nature via AP)
Associated Press Oct. 14, 2015 | 1:06 p.m. EDT + More By MALCOLM RITTER, AP Science Writer
NEW YORK (AP) â€” Scientists say dozens of fossil human teeth from a cave in China show that people lived in southern Asia more than 80,000 years ago,
That's more than 30,000 years earlier than the fossil record had previously established.
Our species, Homo sapiens, is thought to have appeared in Africa around 200,000 years ago. The details of its dispersal from there are still murky.
The scientists report finding 47 teeth in a study released Wednesday by the journal Nature. They estimated that the teeth are 80,000 to 120,000 years old.
The researchers said the finding raises the question of why it took so long for our species to enter Europe later on. They said maybe it was because Neanderthals were already there.
